references.paper_title: Feed two birds with one scone: Exploiting wild data for both out-of-distribution generalization and detection
references.reason: This paper introduces a novel framework addressing both OOD generalization and detection simultaneously, leveraging unlabeled wild data, which directly relates to the core methodology of the current paper.

references.paper_title: Provable guarantees for self-supervised deep learning with spectral contrastive loss
references.reason: This paper provides theoretical guarantees for self-supervised deep learning using spectral contrastive loss, which is foundational to the graph-spectral method used in the current paper.

references.paper_title: A graph-theoretic framework for understanding open-world semi-supervised learning
references.reason: This paper extends the graph-theoretic framework to open-world semi-supervised learning, providing a theoretical foundation for the current paper's approach.

references.paper_title: In search of lost domain generalization
references.reason: This paper discusses the challenges of domain generalization and introduces a new benchmark for evaluating the robustness of machine learning models under different data distributions, which is relevant to the OOD generalization problem tackled in the current paper.

references.paper_title: WILDS: A benchmark of in-the-wild distribution shifts
references.reason: This paper introduces a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating machine learning models under real-world distribution shifts, providing insights and data for the OOD problems investigated in the current paper.
